Unset private

Need a descriptive message like the other options for e.g
--get | -g         Get Version ID
"--version | -v" option instead of "--get" will be more meaningful here.

Does this mean we should implement --version | -v;
                                   --link status | -l
                                   --capabilities | -c
                                   --parameters. | -p
                                   --ncsi        | -n
                                   --controller packet | c
   instead of ...  --get | -g  (x)yz (x = c/l/n/p/v)
Done

How much additional modification is expected?
If there are more 'get' style pending then perhaps
-g <extra-option>
paradigm makes more sense.

I'd rather not see 'version' used for get-channel-version.
--version usually means the version of the program.
gcc --version
gcc (GCC) 14.1.1 20240701 (Red Hat 14.1.1-7)

I expect ncsi-netlink to follow common models.

Jonathan this impacts at least six modifications from six of us.
The above mentioned --get(s). (Link status,caps,parms,ncsi, cntrl pkt,version)
I was using --get xyz 1st but then there was a request for a change to --version.
I was concerned with conflicting one-character <extra-argument>s.
I then realized that --get or -g is an added argument/option which does not help with the conflicts.  
Other modifications in these diffs are using -C(apabilities) & -S(link status) for the short version of an <extra-argument>.
Would you be kind enough to specify here exactly what you prefer for these several "get" operations and i will be happy to implement it and pass it along.   
I am only marking resolved here to encourage some attention here.  Cheers.
I don't see this structure used anywhere in the code.
Done
remote extra space
*remove
Done

We need a standard way of implementing --get xyz in general.
I propose --get:(Capabilities/LinkStat/NCSI/Parameters/Version) ... AND ...
-g (c/l/n/p/v)
Done
Remove this debug print
Done
You don't need to include this header file. You can use the ncsi_util.hpp for any new declaration.
Done
Please move these macros to ncsi_util.hpp header file
Done
Avoid the debug messages
Done
Avoid this message
Done
You don't need this macro of CMT_LINK_STATUS_RESP in the code
I saw it coming in the link status diff.  I'll take it out.
Add the message for Channel params too
Done
doxygen for this?

The comment flower box is in doxygen format right?  It's been to long. 
I just followed the model above. Are you saying we should or should not use doxygen style for the function introduction ?

Does OpenBMC use doxygen?
If this isn't in the repo now, please don't add it.

Remove commented debugging code.
Prefer "\n" to std::endl.
My understanding is "\n" implicitly does a std::flush.
I'm also told std::endl is "\n" && std::flush
Done
Don't push commented code.
Done

[[maybe_unused]] void* arg

If you applied this, I'm curious what issues you saw.
I applied this in other ncsi-netlink commits, and had no problems.
Done
remove in favor of [[maybe_unused]]

I have tried commenting out this line and adding [[maybe_unused]] to the argument in the function header.  In both cases the program displays the results but then hangs waiting for <Cntl>C.  Has anyone else observed this ? I am leaving this as is.
Done

Suggest naming this getVersionID? That is the NCSI command name.
You're retrieving version content from a specific package/channel combination, not the revision of the ncsi-netlink utility.
Done

replace "with in"
should be "within"
Done

Please don't do this.
The revision control system is very good at keeping track of source code changes.

The commit message should describe the changes made, and the reasons the changes are made.

It should complete with a
Tested:
subblock that describes how you tested the code worked as expected.
It should be, IMO, reasonably detailed.
"Passed test suites" is too vague, IMO.
Done
Some suggested changes.
Please update the commit message.

In addition to the inline comments, I have the following comments in response to an email I received on this commit.
For some reason they don't seem to be visible here.
1. It's not recommended to +1 your own submission. I'd recommend sending email requests for attention to non-maintainers. Only after getting all the "Submit Requirements" applied would I email maintainers for attention, and only after allowing the maintainers an opportunity to review on their own schedule.

2. There are numerous commits in flight, each fighting for a command line switch. As I mentioned I consider '-v/--version' apropos of the ncsi_netlink executable version.
We can't really mess with the current set of command line switches without potentially messing up existing users.
At the same time I'd rather not see an alphabet soup of difficult to remember single char switch names.
My suggestion is to add '-o/--option' and then apply mandatory string option names, such as:
-o get-vid, -o get-aen, -o set-aen [1|0], etc....

3. Doxygen: 
   Do not "de-doxygenate" the source. Follow the existing paradigm. If it is doxygen, then ignore my comments regarding adding more like code comments.

No elements from ncsi.h are inside this file.
As a result the ncsi.h file does not need to be in argument.hpp
Done

Why is this added here?
Argument parsing doesn't need ncsi constants does it?
Done

What functions are using cstring and iostream?
Please remove these if they aren't needed.
Done

This is required to terminate the callback.
I did not know that at the time I wrote the comment.
This looked like an unused variable placeholder, thus using maybe_unused.
It would have been nice to have had a comment from the original author indicating it had a purpose.
Done
Done

I recommend following the paradigm I suggested for:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-networkd/+/73039
Where the NCSI_HDR is part of a data structure describing the version ID response packet.
Doing so would get rid of most (all?) of the pointer arithmetic, and the manual std::span creation.
Done

All of these #defines are private to ncsi_util.cpp.
I recommend placing them there.
Done

Henry, We need to incorporate Johnathan Mantey's feedback:

There are numerous commits in flight, each fighting for a command line switch. As I mentioned I consider '-v/--version' apropos of the ncsi_netlink executable version.
We can't really mess with the current set of command line switches without potentially messing up existing users.
At the same time I'd rather not see an alphabet soup of difficult to remember single char switch names.
My suggestion is to add '-o/--option' and then apply mandatory string option names, such as:
-o get-vid, -o get-aen, -o set-aen [1|0], etc....

So, in this case, we need to add -o get-vid instead of --version/-v

Ahsan ... -o (option) is going to conflict with -o (oem-payload).
May i suggest -g / --get vid/lst/ncsi/parms ... etc.  Shouldn't aen be separate ?

Maybe we end up treating -set xyz like -get ?

Please don't change the optionStr parser order for index.
Just add your option alone like this "irsxg:o:p:c:h?"
Please remove these lines as per Johnathan comments. Looks like these changes came back again from the old Patchset 5
Must return int value. Don't comment this line.
You don't need this #define here as you have moved to ncsi_util.cpp
excess blank space
Done
Update syntax
Done
why the _htf?

My results that seem to show this isn't quite correct:
root@bmc-mac0007e9343c6e:/tmp# ncsi-netlink  -x 3 -p 0 -c 0 -g vid
<7> NCSI version (BCD): f1 f1 f0 00  <- not BCD
<7> Firmware version: 00 00 f7 43
<7> PciVendor: 0x8680 <- I expect 0x8086
<7> PciDevice: 0x8680
<7> IANA Manufacturer Id: 343
Done
Done
excise _htf
Done
Some comments on the most recent commit.

Perhaps generalize this?
--get | -g     <option>
    <option> is one of:
    vid: Get NCSI Version ID
    ncsi: Get whatever this gets
    ....: space for future options
Done

IMO, choose one example showing how to use the new feature.
I added these examples because it required reading the source code to figure out what the necessary switch combinations were.
I think one example is sufficient.
Thank you for making this happen before a defacto API congealed.
Done
debug message.... please remove
Use C++ casting?
Done

Perhaps build a templatized toHexStr overload that accepts int types, and does the nasty recasting to std::span inside?
toHexStr(&getVersonIdResp....., sizeof(getVersnIdResp->var))
?
Other people are going to need to do this same casting mess.
I worked around this issue.  The ncsiVersion IS BCD with a wrinkle.

As noted in the commit message comments... this doesn't look correct.
Other commits are collecting the response data, and passing them through a big endian to host endian function to massage the output data.

My brief look at the NCSI spec seems to show the NCSI version is not BCD. Perhaps the FW version is?

Other commits are using a 'convertToHostEndian()' function that returns a reference to the response structure (i.e. getVersionIdResponse& convertEndianess(nla_data...))

Then the return value is sent to an output function (i.e. printNCSIVer()).
See the previous comment
I notice this value is correctly printing 343 for the Intel NCSI device in my system. It's doing so because of the ntohl() call.
Done. Using ntohs for 16-bit little-endian quantities.  I only have zeroes on ourt BMCs.
align with @brief line, as is done in prior prototype.
Done

follow paradigm:
param[in] should be @param[in]
Done
Here are some additional comments on commit 9

I don't know if it is necessary.
Look into whether you need to use __attribute__ ((PACKED)) for these structures.

We don't need/use the completion codes except as a placeholder.
The alignment must be proper because we are retrieving the ncsiVersion data properly.
Remove comment
Done
Done

I am now inclined to approve this.
You need to get your UID added to the Gerrit system by your appointed admin.
After this reaches a Verified +1 I'll add my +1.
OOPS.  I will fix this right away.
We need to remember that the input is a fixed length (6) array of BCD. Three bytes
The length is specified properly  this way.

Need to fix OpenBMC CI Build Errors.

You need to run clang-format -i on the files
Adding Patrick W. as a reviewer
Correcting mistaken advice.
If you use the `unpack()` suggestion above you don't have to dribble `ntoxyz()` functions in the code. The data structure will already be in host endian format.
